Wolfenstein 2 is a great FPS game held back by terrible dialogue and short play time. If the game cut 90% of the dialogue, added 5-10 more hours of playtime (you're looking at about 10-12 hours to do the story) it would be worth your money. As it currently stands it doesn't justify the asking price. Buy it on sale, mute the cut scenes, enjoy shooting Nazis in the face.

I was completely unaware of HyperParasite's (HP) existence, until the developer contacted Save or Quit about reviewing the game, with a statement that it'd be well-suited for, â€œSomeone who eats Enter the Gungeon and Binding of Isaac for breakfast.â€ Intrigued, I checked out the store page, saw that it had a respectable number of reviews and overall rating, and decided I'd throw down on that sort of challenge. Especially since I've not actually played those two games that had been referenced. I'm skipping breakfast and taking this game to lunch.   HP is a twin stick shooter, rogue lite, with you controlling a fairly weak parasite. It can kill enemies, but being hit takes away one of your lives, and you start each run with only 1. At the earliest possibility, you'll want to inhabit a suitable host, since if the host dies, it doesn't impact the parasite. Plus, their attack power is significantly stronger. In spite of being able to find upgrades and skills during runs, there are no permanent stat increases, as each run has you start in a random body. In this review, I'll only address how HP plays in 80's Mode, as that's the default mode to play in.  So, how do you get stronger? By being a good parasite, of course. At first, you're surrounded by enemies that are useless to you, because they have a padlock icon over them indicating you can't possess them. What you'll want to find are red ringed enemies, that you can never possess. However, if it's not a host you've already unlocked, killing it produces a brain, which you take to the shop and unlock with money. From then on, you can possess that enemy as often as you want. Unlocked bodies only pertain to each individual zone, of which there are 5, with each new location forcing you to start from scratch.     It's possible to play this game with the keyboard, but I found it worked quite well with a controller. Movement is controlled with the 'L joystick' while aiming is done with the 'R joystick.' Interacting with objects is done by tapping or holding down the 'A button,' while 'B' backs out of menus. Holding down 'X' self-destructs your current host, and 'Y' activates green items. The 'R trigger' is your attack button, and 'R bumper' reloads firearms. 'L trigger' activates your special attack, while 'L bumper' is your dodge roll. 'Select' brings up your map, from which you can teleport to rooms, and 'Start' brings up the menu.   At the start of HP, an opening cutscene plays out, with the POTUS warning people about an alien parasite stealing bodies. Your goal is to take possession of the POTUS and launch the nuclear arsenal to wipe out all human life. With intelligence agencies determining your goal but not your location, everyone has been ordered to eliminate you, though I don't know how they recognize you while inside a host. Plus, whenever someone would determine where you are, why not call in a nuclear strike on that area? Because there wouldn't be a game, of course!  The game's graphics don't scream 80's to me the way others say. The various host bodies are certainly references to media from that time, but the visuals otherwise make me think of games made within the last few years. HP isn't a pixelated game, and there are details present in each environment, such as the litter, trash fires, and neon signs in the Downtown area. However, I don't care much for the graphics, as it has a washed out look because the edges don't look crisp but somewhat blurred, and the backgrounds are quite random with their colors.   I find the title theme unpleasant, as it has a strange pitch to it. Otherwise, I think the music is reasonably good in HP. When you're exploring stages without enemies around, the game plays a calmer track. However, when you're locked in combat, it speeds up and plays a more aggressive song. The music does change for each zone, but I don't recall there being a variety of songs in each area. HP would benefit from more versatility in the music selection, especially with how much you replay the same spots.   ðŸŒŸ I like the variety of enemies in the game, including some of the creative weaponry. For instance, the basketball player who throws basketballs, or the ex-FBI agent who shoots a paperclip gun.  ðŸŒŸ There are currently 2 game modes available, with plans to release other modes in future updates. Plus, the game has local coop.   âŒ Some details aren't explained very well in HP. For instance, what luck has an effect on, which order you need to navigate alternative routes in, how you're supposed to get past barriers like the garbage dumpster or the void, etc.  âŒ Since all money is lost when you fail a run, and buying host bodies is the only way to cause a permanent effect, it's very easy to make a decent run, but make no progress whatsoever from it.  âŒ RNG plays a big role in your runs: whether you'll have access to the shop at a convenient time, the quality of skills available, and how much money you get since its luck-dependent.  ðŸ” Though you will be outgunned and in tough situations, enemies are easy to manipulate. If you get out of their line of sight by taking cover, they'll pause before rushing toward you, which is a great opportunity to turn the corner and blast them.  ðŸ” Putting bodies into storage allows you to access them from any other Wito shop within the same run. So, if you've not unlocked a host body in the 3rd area, you can have spare bodies waiting for you once you get there.  ðŸ” There are consistent items in each main area: Wito's shop, at least 3 upgrades, 1 secret item, 1 mini-boss, and 1 elite enemy.   At first, when I saw less hosts in upcoming zones, I was somewhat disappointed. However, as I put more than a dozen hours into HP, I was exasperated by how many remained. The unique gameplay of HP in turn creates a unique downside. Since the trade-off you make for not having permanent stat upgrades is access to an endless pool of spare bodies to inhabit, the start of each run starts playing the same way each time, as a boring routine. Although the overwhelming advantage shifting to your favor is fun at first, when you have to kill every enemy to clear rooms and get to the next zone, it gets old quick. Especially since you have to make each run count by finding all the upgrades and skills that you can, because you need them to make progress in the later areas where you don't have several hosts already unlocked.  This is what made me give up on going further with HP. Not because it was too hard, but because investing so much time just to put a few drops in the bucket in later areas was so unrewarding and frustrating. By the time I quit, I was able to consistently clear the first 3 bosses, and had taken down the 4th boss on my first attempt fighting it. Without a way to shave off some of this needless repetition, I've no interest in playing this further, and don't recommend it in its current state.

First the game has lots of bots and gold sellers. So the economy is broken some itens cost millions when you barely make 1 million playing all day at end game level. At the lower level where you could use soem good itens you cant buy them because they are over priced due the gold sellers and bots. I have 180 hours, barely managed to get my first character to level 160, the game is fun has some potential on the way you can mix character classes, but the way the class tree's work you are bound to see lots of the same builds. Yeah the game has lots of classes, but you can start on 4 path's: Wizzard, Cleric, Archer and Swordsman. Those have their own class tree and you cant mix classes between those different path's. But you can mix the classes on one of those path's, that can be fun, but for pvp or if you want a character that have sinergy and deal good damage you will be tied to some classes and will not be able to custumize much your character. The status growth is a joke, for wizzards not only the support classes but the damage dealers to, it's better to upgrade much more your constitution than your int, because the int only upgrade your damage be 1 and after 10 or 20 points it gives you a bonus that barely changes anything. So a perfect wizzard class for pvp will have 200+ con and barely past 30 int. So that make this game a little joke for some classes, they relly on flat damage from skill's than damage from status upgrade. There's some other problems if you want to not be a premium, since you will have some limitations to Auction House and to trade's and some other small things. But you can be a premium with game currency that you get from killing monsters and the cost is affordable. The game is fun and all but i cant recommend it the way it's right now, there's some problems with the server where you get disconnected a lot from time to time, and weekends we get rubberband effect a lot, you cant a spell the character move like the spell was done but nothing happens except the monsters dont get the lag and them hit you. TLDR: Game need's better staff, hardware, and a revamp on the way status influence the damage.

Super old graphics, boring gameplay and boring quests. Don't waste your time, there's just too much better mmorpg's out there that do a better job and are decent.

The campaign is uninteresting and boring. You're never told why you need to save this guy or kill that guy or whatever. After almost every mission, this generic soldier dude appears, says "train go boom" like he's the coolest guy ever and then vanishes. Then you are blinded by a bright light (or something like that) and you're back at the hub, preparing for another mission. You don't even have a name. Your name is literally 'player'. What!? If they wanted to give players the opportunity to create their own characters, they should have given us more options. You can only choose from a selection of faces for the protagonist (or 'your' character) and you don't even have the option to choose a black man's face. They're all white. What!? That's racist!  As if the player base wasn't low enough on pc, the 4 dlc packs as well as the season pass has divided the player base even further. There is literally NO ONE in the 'No DLC' playlists. So I guess screw me 'cause I decided get the standard edition rather than the deluxe edition. And no, I don't have anything to say about the actual multiplayer gameplay because I haven't had the pleasure to play it at all. I've searched all the (active) playlists for several minutes but I guess I have to spend another 50 bucks (or 25 on sale) to actually get to play the multiplayer. And there ain't no way in hell am I gonna do that.  Ahh, the zombies mode. I got the game for 3 reasons: 1) split screen for all modes on pc. 2) multiplayer (which doesn't even work for me). and 3) zombies. I wanted to play the zombies mode in split screen as I don't really enjoy playing it alone. But the split screen doesn't work! :D the game freezes every time I try to play zombies in split screen mode!!! YAYY :D. And now even if I manage to run it and it turns out to be great, my opinion about this game ain't never gonna change unless the multiplayer miraculously gets populated.  DON'T GET THIS GAME if you intend to get the standard edition or for the campaign. As for the zombies, I really can't say, as I wasn't fortunate enough to get it to work.

I was really hoping for a nice pawn shop game like Pickers, but instead am confronted by spiritually disgusting Satanic secret society junk.  It really disturbs me how many games and other forms of media contain such spiritual and mental sickness.  If it didn't have this twisted aspect, I think I would really enjoy the game. The female characters sound like dudes trying to sound like women which is ridiculous which makes me think the guys who made this have no women in their lives to do voice overs. I'm not a fan of the jumping puzzles and find them frustrating.  Why is water instant death?  Is it because this game was made by witches afraid of melting? The wall mount items clip with the most expensive wall mount.  Otherwise, I like that I can upgrade the shop.  It would be nice to be able to upgrade the sleeping quarters as well. I haven't finished the game yet, so I may add more later.

Do not buy this game. This game is still clearly in pre-alpha. Periscope Games have no knowledge of how guns work aside from the look and sound. Vehicles still cannot drive through fences unless you are going Mach 5. Spawns are ass backwards. The enemy spawns closer to objectives than you do.  For the first time in your life, trust a Jew. This game is not worth the $30 you'd be paying for it.

Tons of lampooning of everything sci-fi. It's pretty interesting. But for someone that actually wants the achievements the spaceship controls are so bad they're laughable. Except you can't laugh because you actually need to maneuver and hit fast targets with the spaceship for the achievements. It was infuriating. I understand adding in bad controls. They do it in other parts of the game. But with the bike, for example, the achievement is easy. The spaceship achievements require luck and keeping your blood from boiling. It's a completionist's nightmare. I also tend to phase through the floor way too often. Casually it's fun, but for completionism it's pretty abominable.

I played on the ps4, but sadly dropped because of the controls, that I found to be really annoying. Now I bought the game on PC and the KM combo is amazing, I played yesterday (07/08/2020), with 1 crash the game is running at 40+ fps 1440p on my 2070ti+2700x (the settings don't matter, it always stays there, the game seems to have some problem with higher than 1080p resolutions), other than the gaps I found no problem during my playtime. But now I entered the village, today (08/08/2020) and every 5-10 minutes the game crashes, making it unplayable for me. The benchmark is also a lie, it doesn't if you want to buy Horizon w8 for a promo, because right now the game is unplayable.

This game, 100%, is early access, even tho it doesn't say so.  Very good game. amazing graphics as long as you flying 1000+ feet above the terrain, the AI built world is an amazing innovation, but its not without its problems. and very graphically intensive in large cities.   This game crashes and freezes more than any early access game i have ever played. and its not early access - plenty of others having similar issues. Makes it very hard to recommend. so for the moment, i don't.  wait a few months for the bugs to be worked out. other than that tho.  its a lot of fun to jump in the Pitts Special and send it through your home town

Il sistema di combattimento Ã¨ superficiale, hai tante abilitÃ  e soluzione su come fronteggiare il nemico di turno ma il tutto si riduce nello sperare di incontrare qualcuno con un livello piÃ¹ alto del tuo. is the dictionary definition of "Asset Flip." The experience is laughably short, comprised of just two 3-minute missions, has the most basic A.I. imaginable, and is inhabited by barely altered low poly models seen in far too many games already overpopulating Steam. I'm not even going to bother to do my usual Pro/Con breakdown, this isn't a game, it's barely even a tech demo. I'll give the developer credit that the first stage environment is visually interesting, but that's as far as it goes. The castle stage has a far more fun-looking town just north of your spawn point, but it's devoid of life, and no structures can be entered. Everything is window dressing to hide the fact that the game has zero substance. Enemies are dumb as a rock, capable of only the most basic attack. Apparently, if you hit several in close proximity, they will start to turn on each other until only one is left standing. Is this an intentional feature? Whatever the case, it trivializes the game's already anemic difficulty. Stage 2 has you climbing castle walls, but this mechanic only works when standing on giant "climb" buttons which vanish after use. Once you reach the holding cell of your fellow tribeswomen, the game abruptly ends. I'm not sure if there is a legitimate way to enter the cell other than from above... I kept swinging a sword until I clipped through the gate by accident. And finally,   doesn't even deserve the Hentai in its title, obviously added for sales effect. Nudity in this game is equivalent to looking at a Barbie doll. What's the point of being able to toggle clothes in the first place when you can already see through their revealing leaf coverings? For collectors only. Consider this game at risk for removal, should Valve QC decide to start doing their job. : Extremely easy. Complete both stages, double click the nude option in the main menu. You're done in under 10 minutes if you don't explore.
Terrible optimisation, terrible textures, i don't know, how it's change in the future but i don't want to wait, i want to play right now! Unfortunately this is bad start for good game.

The game has several interface issues, both in menus and in play. This can lead to frustrating, unintended gameplay interactions, as well as locked up menus (requiring a game restart) or sounds that ignore your in-game volume settings, or so forth. All on top of a woeful lack of access to any kind of menu interface while in a match (ie, to adjust sounds, leave the match, etc). The game only has a 5 minute tutorial mode for single player, there's no actual campaign. I couldn't find any co-op functionality at all (presumably the developer isn't very familiar with games and instead intended to reference local pvp), so the game is mislabeled. At a glance, the game balance appears iffy in places. The core concept and the manner by which the physics interact is very appealing, but this game appears to be nothing more than an abandoned prototype at its current state. Given that it's free, it's an interesting proof of concept for a full-fledged future game (one that I'd personally be interested in playing), but it doesn't yet have either the polish or the substance to be recommended to anyone for play.  If you're simply curious about the concept and have 5 - 10 minutes to kill, go ahead and give this a shot. However, if you're looking for something you can actually get some real gameplay in on, give this one a hard skip.

Played it for a couple minutes and I wanted to literally break my controller in half.  I even went through the trouble of researching if a real rally car even controls like that and long story short, it doesn't. At least the base controls the game gives you right off bat aren't and customising it to my liking felt like an unbelievably tedious task. The fact that you have to load into a match just to test whether or not those settings are to your liking is just stupidity to me as well.  I can see the appeal but it just isn't for me, cars are just too damn slippery and control to unrealistically for my liking. You can literally perform a complete 360 degrees side flip by just knocking a corner which is just laughable. Also make no mistake, I enjoy difficult games that feel fair like From Soft's games or the Ninja Gaiden games but I feel pure frustration every time I load up a match and it just doesn't feel fair to me, glad I didn't waste my money on this.  I wont even review the game since I have completely no interest in rally racers and I don't think I'd ever touch it again, let alone complete it.

I loved the Double Dragon series growing up. Played it in the arcades and on some of the home consoles. The Steam version is OKAY but marred by control issues. I haven't experienced any game crashes, like some other reviewers have mentioned, even with 2 players. The game is $5.99 and the lowest it has ever been was $1.49. I cannot recommend the game at the regular price. The developer hasn't updated the game in over two years (at the time of this review) and it has a number of issues that should be addressed. If you can snatch it up for $1.49? It might be worth your time but even at that price you can find a better game.

Pros: Interesting concept satisfying combat (once you get used to the controls). The music is great, and adds to the already immersive atmosphere of the game. Enjoyable to play, to the point where game breaking bugs creep in (and they WILL creep in. Just read the other reviews if you aren't convinced.) Cons: Guidance and "wiki" material is lackluster at best. Inventory management is awful. GAME BREAKING BUGS. Overall: With some games, the experience can help you overlook the bugs in a game. With this game, the bugs influence your experience - to the point of breaking it. The good news is the devs seem to be activelly working on the game. Wait until the game is correctly patched.

I remember the days, when combat racing games were all the hype. Those are early Blizzard days, when they've released the game I've mentioned above. They've truly opened a Pandora's box with that one. Formula of making a game like that hasn't changed since those days, too: you take your isometric camera, place it over a plainly shaped track, scatter some bonuses around, add very little to no car variation, and -- voila! -- your game is ready to be published. I realize, that the game I'm reviewing right now is 6 years old, but then again, so is  , another combat racing game, another Rock'n'Roll Racing rip-off. And while this game aged like milk, BlazeRush is still extremely fun to play, if you're into the genre. All in all, combat racing games are dead nowadays, cause no greedy published has yet found a way to add microtransactions or lootboxes to it (which does sound fairly easy, to think of it). As for the game, well, like I said: the formula hasn't changed since 1993. You grind cash on your races, you upgrade your car, you progress, open new tracks, buy new cars, upgrade further, rinse & repeat. Graphics are outdated, UI is plainly terrible, controls are too arcade (even for an arcade game), characters are something you'll forget as quickly as 10 seconds after turning off the game. Definitely not, there's a plenty of significantly better outdated combat racing games.

Llevo jugando desde el 2006 a un juego muy similar del mismo creador, concretamente el Netsoccer 1 y posteriormente otra version mejorada llamada Netsoccer 2, este juego tiene bastantes similitudes con aquellos juegos aunque tambien tiene importantes diferencias, para no hacerlo muy extenso paso a resaltar los pros y contras del juego : Pros : ------ - Es adictivo, en cuanto aprendes a jugar quieres jugar un partido y otro partido y otro partido...esta claro que es un juego al que si le pillas el truco vas a querer jugarle mucho. - Acostumbrados en las anteriores versiones a coincidir siempre 5 jugadores para poder jugar la verdad es que tener tanta gente online y la posibilidad de jugar a casi cualquier hora del dia se agradece, es un plus que solo la gente que venimos del otro juego entendemos. - Los menus son intuitivos, puedes crear tu propio equipo, repartir dentro de los mismos distintos niveles (owner, master, admin y player), tiene un apartado de competiciones que entiendo se ira puliendo...por ahora la cosa pinta bien al respecto. Tienes estadisticas tantos de equipos como de jugadores. - Controles muy sencillos, yo recomiendo siempre el raton, con el raton y la tecla "a" para segar ya no necesitas mas. Contras -------- - El lag, eso lo principal, esta mejorando pero es un gran problema. - Lo siento pero no voy a pagar 7 eurazos por 3 meses de VIP, aun recuerdo pagar 12 euros por un aÃ±o en el otro juego. - Muy lento, seria mucho mas divertido si los jugadores fueran mas rapidos. - Tendria que existir algun modo de aprendizaje, un tutorial dentro del juego para los nuevos jugadores. - Los BOTS, aunque la gente que lleva poco dice que son buenos, son absurdos y rompen mucho la dinamica del juego, yo lo cambiaria claramente por un minimo de jugadores humanos quitando los bots. Recalco, no son buenos, hay muchos trucos para evitarlos en ataque. - Los bugs, hay varios como por ejemplo centrar al primer palo desde el corner, es siempre gol si te colocas bien. - El portero, es bastante inutil, si aprendes a tirar desde un sitio el 95% de los disparos son gol. - Si juegas contra un VIP y tu no eres VIP estas perdido, actualmente en ese aspecto es un pay to win clarisimo. A nivel grafico no comento nada ya que cumple con su cometido, lo principal es el gameplay, lo mismo el sonido... En resumen, no pretendas entrar y empezar a "disfrutar", es un juego que parece simple pero necesita mucha practica para disfrutarle, yo recomiendo entrenar mucho y jugar partidos contra amigos para ir pillando el truco. Podeis pedirme ayuda y consejos dentro del juego, no tengo problemas al respecto, bastante gente me ha preguntado ya. Â¿Lo recomiendo?, por ahora si ya que tengo fe en su creador que lo conozco hace muchos aÃ±os y tengo la esperanza de que vaya lanzando actualizaciones y puliendo todos los problemas. Darle una oportunidad y no os rindais, es cuestion de practica y sobre todo paciencia. EDITO ANALISIS - El desarrollador ha cerrado el juego, no carga sin previo aviso...algo totalmente inesperado y mÃ¡s cuando hay gente que ha pagado el VIP y no se sabe que ha pasado con su dinero...obviamente cambio a NO RECOMENDADO por la nula evoluciÃ³n en actualizaciones del juego y por cerrarle de este modo.

We've come a long way with this game. We had some ups and downs but, overall, it's undeniable that Payday2 Is a great game and that, for the most part, Overkill behaved well towards their gaming community.  Unfortunately, that ends today. There's no more trust to be had towards Overkill and their Microtransactions update for an event where everything was promised free. This is a payed game, with lots of payed DLC (LOTS) and despite their promises two years ago: "We've made it clear that PAYDAY 2 will have no micro-transactions whatsoever (shame on you if you thought otherwise!)" Overkill has broken their word. Until this changes, stay away from Payday 2, as much as it saddens me to say so...

Toby is a humanoid being with horns whose friends have been kidnapped by demonic-looking red-eyed villains. Your side quest is to reach and release them, with a lot of them found in hidden alcoves and just out of sight of the beaten path. But the main mission is to negotiate the gameâ€™s puzzle-platforming sequences, continuously avoiding Tobyâ€™s death. This game is obviously heavily 'inspired' by Limbo but it maintains its own personality, being a shorter and coloured proposal. Although the game looks pretty nice with its art style making use of shadow and minimalistic design for its 2D protagonist. It can't escape having a cartoony feel that doesn't suit the dark tone it's aiming for.  Controls are fairly simple, with a jump button allowing you to make leaps between platforms and an action button for pulling levers. In the opening few levels, the platforming is kept relatively simple and straightforward, but as you progress deeper into the game you're faced with more complex and twitch based sections. These sections don't mesh well with the floaty jumping and leave you with plenty of frustrating deaths. Seriously, lots of them. The puzzle solving, on the other hand, is mostly a much more enjoyable experience. The difficulty is scaled almost perfectly here. You'll encounter physics based puzzles and simple switch puzzles, as well as more complex puzzles involving the use of light and a need to pay close attention to your surrounding environment. Unfortunately, there are a few conundrums present that are mostly just left up to guess work. These puzzles can thankfully be brute forced rather quickly, but it still impedes your enjoyment. In conclusion, Toby The Secret mine is a decently yet frustrating 2d platformer for someone looking play another puzzle platformer that won't take up much time. Buy you probably, prefer to give Limbo a try instead. Thanks   for this gift! <3

Feels like a classic Blizzard launch.  I have lagged out randomly and it keeps saying to check my hardware etc. etc. Seeing as how only 37% of my CPU and 46% of my memory is being used I am not seeing an issue at all. On top of that no matter the graphics setting I have it on be it max or lowest, I still lag out. So best possible answer is that you were not prepared for launch.  Now mid strike I got crashed with the following error:  "Problem reading game content. Please close Destiny 2, right click on Destiny 2 in the Steam app to run 'VERIFY INTEGRITY OF GAME FILES...' in 'properties'. Then restart Destiny 2 to try again." After doing this, everything was 100% fine, but still get the same errors and even others that make absolutely no sense. Fix your stuff before launching it or at least make it capable of handling people. Edit: Finally fixed it a couple days ago. The game was refusing to detect my VRAM properly. Took A LOT of work for it to function properly. A lot more than it should have which is why I still mark this as a No on recommendation.

don't buy it. period

don't buy it. save yourselves. highly addicting. it would be worth the addiction if the material was of good quality. it's not and yet u wouldn't be able to stop it. why? F**ING REWARD LOOP that pubg is famous for. it's called dopamine loop too. it's like gambling. u do it until u win and even when u win u do it again to win again. the possibilities in this game are unlimited. the place u land, the guns u get, if a player sees u while u're going to the circle, if that player is good or bad so u have time to react, if u face a macro user, if u do or don't get a bug, if u're not scissored by two snipers, if the special care package is dropped next to you, if when its 1vs1, the circle changes a way that u have a good cover and your opponent has to leave cover and move inside the circle so u can shoot him easily, if when 3 ppl are remaining 2 other get busy fighting and u can move fast inside the circle and not get hit by that sniper on top of the mountain (who's busy atm) while doing so. lots and lots of ifs. and u do it because u hope in one situation u can win. its called "near miss" effect similar to one we see with gambling which makes u think if u do it again u can win because u were close to a win last time u lost. this makes it a unique game in terms of addiction comparing to other competitive games like CSGO.

No se porque me sorprende no recomendarlo, cuando era tan obvio lo que iba a encontrar, pero resulta que es peor que eso. Esperaba encontrar una copia de CoD:MW bastante mas tarde por parte de la competencia y es eso pero con muchos fallos. El primero y el que mas me molesto es que no tenes problemas de municion bajo ningun concepto, solo tenes que pedirle a uno de tus compaÃ±eros cuando te queden pocas y.... magia, todos los cargadores a tope compaÃ±ero. Y si bien eso no es algo tan obsceno como para darle negativo con tan pocas horas de juego, a pesar de que aunque no lo parezca iba como por la quinta mision porque son demasiado faciles y cortas. Lo que logro esto fue llegar a una mision donde habia una nube de polvo donde casi ni se podia ver y solo te decian que tenias que limpiar la zona de enemigos, excelente si tan solo pudiera verlos capas lo intento.  Igual quizas no sea tan malo como lo describo pero, en mi opinion creo que este titulo fue el ultimo manotazo de ahogado para tratar de revivir una saga tan grande y vieja como era Medal of Honor.

While i know this isn't Road Rash, it's too close to it not to try to ride on that nostalgia wave. However, where Road Rash was a fun and enjoyable motorracing game with additional combat, Road Redemption is more of a rogue-like fighting-game on motorbikes. Controls feel sluggish, weird and not always as responsive as they should be and frequent crashes into things, as you're swarmed by enemies, was a constant pain. The rogue-like part actually fits quite good and the mad max like theme is quite intriguing but nothing really stands out. Neither the music, nor the graphics, nor the gameplay are above average and that's why it's getting boring pretty fast for me. It's uninspired button-smashing, repetitive missions (race, survive, kill x amount of...) and grindy structures to unlock new bikes and players. Hard pass for me.

Overhyped, grindy, boring/repetitive survival game with massive time-gates and very poor optimisation. Yeah, I didn't like it at all. "You are cold. You are hot. You are thirsty. You are hungry. Plaaaaaaap - you have just taken a dump." - sums up my time in the game. Ark is a survival game similar to games like Rust, 7DTD, Grav - but with dinosaurs. That's pretty much it really. Graphically it looks pretty enough, but the game is so poorly optimised it's laughable. Couple this with the fact it doesn't even have VSYNC, G-SYNC or a frame rate limiter means your GPU will be constantly running maxed out. It suffers from bugs like clipping errors a lot. At one point I got stuck standing on an unconscious dino and the only way off was for another player to kill me. Gameplay is also plagued with issues. Firstly, "Busywork". Repetitive, boring busywork. The game is chock-full of it. A technique a lot of games these days employ to extend play time - even some of the AAA ones. It's lazy and is a trend I wish we could get rid of. You will spend the majority of your time in Ark collecting, mining and chopping down trees. This is coupled with the grind. Even with our server set at 4x for XP, taming, resources and the like, it's a very long and painful grind. The game stops you from building things until you have reached a certain level, things like taming taking an age and the general "artificial wall" this game applies to slow down your progress is dreadful. This is worsened when you factor in level discrepancies with other players. The game punishes the players that don't play as much and creates a rift - like many other games of similar ilk. Given the amount of time required to get anywhere in this game, it's a mechanic that punishes people who do not play every day. There is apparently an endgame where you have to kill endgame bosses. However, it's not something that inspires me to continue at all. The majority of the game is the journey - and when that isn't fun then I have no desire to see how it ends. It gives me zero incentive to spend potentially hundreds of hours farting about just so I can kill a big dinosaur and call it quits. So, what's to like? The ability to tame and ride dinosaurs is cool (although ruined due to the time gating and grind). You get the feeling this game could have been something really special, had the developers cared as much for gameplay as they did grind. The combat is okay. Nothing good or bad there. Crafting is okay. The terrain is unfortunately not alterable, but the structures and things you can build is pretty decent - so there is definitely something there for those that like making things. It lacks depth, but is serviceable. That's it, really. Summary: below average survival game with dinosaurs, severe grind and boring busywork, consisting of 90% of your time.

Too much hype for a bad game. The game, itself, taking every bit of context, is not that bad. It's just a copy of every other game that came before, with hack 'n slash combat, puzzle-solving and weapon upgrade. But when you put it all in what this game promised, after the name 'Castlevania', and after the previous game, it is a complete failure, a letdown. Graphics are amazing, can't deny that. From scenery, to character design and artwork/concept. Now, gameplay is generic, and story is  lame, predictable, bland. Most of the characters are poorly written and have no personality, only doing what the plot needs it to do. And the end is anti-climatic. Skip it.

After years of playing this game and a lot of money spent on skins and cases, having approximately 4000h in my 2 accounts combined, I have to say I had to uninstall it. I had not played CS:GO in 3 months before this review because I was tired of the amount of cheaters I was playing against (I have a prime account and my rank was Legendary Eagle/Legendary Eagle Master). I spent those 3 months playing Rainbow Six Siege a game which I disregarded for a lot of time because I prefered CS:GO over it, and I still do when it comes to the gameplay itself. So, today, I thought, I'm gonna give CS:GO another chance and so, me and my friend queued up, and, I swear to god, in our very first game we get an HvH situation. I left mid game and uninstalled CS:GO right away. I love this game, but I cannot recommend it until it gets a decent enough anticheat (and 128 tick servers would be nice as well!) It really saddens me that I can't play the game I love the most, but this is the truth, in its current state, CS:GO regular matchmaking is unplayable, if you want to have a lesser chance of finding cheaters you need to go to FaceIt or similar platforms. Please Valve, set your skins and stickers aside for just a minute and give us a better anti-cheat. After that you can go right back to making money.

BAD ANTI-CHEAT

I heard this was easy to 100% and it was already in my library so I gave it a shot. It took about 2 minutes of play to get all 5 achievements without actually trying to do anything. You navigate a cube through a maze with timing based puzzles. That's all there is to it. The GUI is very amateurish and ugly. It looks like a student game. It's also impossible to tell which level you're on. Verdict: Get the achievements and get out.

This is a 'start-over-simulator'. Cons: - you have to run a lot, but you will fail to a one-shot thing and start over with running. - no xp like in alpha. - poor progression. - overall just worse than the alpha. - too many cons to list. Pros: - more new creatures/monsters than the alpha. but that's also a con, because, it quickly becomes pointless. - you can use cheat engine to fast forward most of the very boring running. - quests! But this is also a con, because now you have to run again and quest rewards suck. I had high hopes for this game. I never expected it to be worse than the alpha. I'm 110% sure someone killed the old dev and is wearing his skin. I would alert the authorities, but I don't have enough proof.. yet.

was exactly what I was expecting it to be but hoping it wouldnâ€™t! Much like VTM:Bloodlines and Red Embrace: Hollywood (I havenâ€™t played Coteries of New York), you play as a recently turned fledgling whose sire isnâ€™t in the picture. This time you play as Julia, a former investigative journalist who is now the bottom of the barrel in vampire society. Self-loathing, outspoken and a chronic chain smoker. The future doesnâ€™t look bright for this lost soul â€“ well literally because you know, no sun. When a sudden murder needs investigating, Julia is thrown head first into a political game that she is not only unqualified for, but also no one is really willing to help her out. Itâ€™s clear she is a pawn and a disposable one but being the type of person she is, she soldiers on in the hopes of busting this case wide open.   Needless to say, this shares a lot of common ground with other vampire games; newly turned. No sire to guide her. Shouldered with responsibilities far above her status and way too much politics; itâ€™s not exactly original. This version also has a heavy side dose of religion. Nether are things I really enjoy reading. I do however, like being the underdog that no one really suspects. The one everyone takes for granted and doesnâ€™t believe will ever succeed. Extra points for being sassy too.   The artwork is beautifully dark and envisions children of the night quite nicely with itâ€™s gritty, stylish and grungy design. Animated backgrounds and atmospheric sounds/music really push this to the next level as well. As someone who can appreciate the beauty in darkness, this was nice eye candy for my twisted little mind. The cast of eccentric characters was the cherry on the top to this delicious ice-cream Sunday!    Considering Vampire: The Masquerade is in itâ€™s own universe I was a little annoyed when there was mentions of a pandemic that originated from China in 2020 â€“ I mean, really? REALLY? I donâ€™t know about other people but I play games to get away from all that chaos outside. I donâ€™t want it to needlessly show up in the thing Iâ€™m trying to use to escape mention of the damn virus and when I say â€œneedlesslyâ€, I do mean it. It literally had no effect on the story what so ever apart from a few lines here and there that could quite easily have been replaced with â€“ oh I donâ€™t know â€“ anything else!!   Something that really let me down was the sheer lack of clan traits. For example, Iâ€™m a huge fan of Malkavianâ€™s. I adore the insanity that was displayed in VTM:B but there was no crazy to be found here. In fact, only Julia really displayed any clan traits and that was merely necessity to keep the relationship with her human friend for the ending decisions. Completely disappointed!  The choice on how you get the good and bad ending was    To get the good ending    To get the bad ending   Overall, not a fan of the visual novel version and Iâ€™d be very hard pressed to recommend this to anyone.

The game looks amazing but i'm having a lot of problems with the game not running smooth. I mean i'm getting around 250 FPS.. In my opinion if you are playing an Arena shooter the gameplay must be so smooth you almost feel like you're in the game, and actually controlling the character. People who have played Q3A, Counter-strike and other classics know what i am talking about. I had nothing of this experience in this game because the game is just not optimized. If the developers are deciding to update the game and fix their problems i'm willing to edit this review. In Quake Champions you are able to choose from various champions to play with with either their own special skill and stats. For example, one champion can teleport each 30 seconds, and have extra or less health, armour or speed. There are also loot boxes in this game which grant you with special weapon and champion skins. It's a cool idea, but almost every other FPS game nowadays has this feature. I am not recommending this game as a fan of the original Quake games because i am really missing the smooth fast-paced action Quake is known about.

If you are not deeply into the building mechanics of this game stay far away from it. Its depends fully on mods and its community to be anything at all and what I encountered did no impress me at all but it might simply not be for me. Its a sandbox with a fair amount of tools but what you will most likely encounter if you go in blind will make you want to never touch the game again. It has a fairly simply list of achievements to introduce you to different parts of the game but has some really frustrating ones. One of them being for being on a server with 31 other people which is quite a rare thing and the more time that passes the harder it will become. When I got it there was only a single server close to those numbers, and I was only able to boost it high enough by asking friends with the game to join the server. But the most annoying achievement in the game goes to the race achievements. Its fairly simply as far as the idea goes; you need to complete an SP race and win a MP race on someone else's server...shouldnt be too bad if the driving mechanics was ok, but they are really bad. The driving is super floaty, and you can go of the track really easy forcing you to start all over.  1-3 hours (depending on your luck)

Originally thought it was a fun game that had a great "story line". Turned out to be a game full of bugs and constant randomness. Constantly died from random bugs and thing. We not recommend to any one. This is truly a game that you should look at from a far if you want to actually enjoy it, aka watch youtube videos of people struggling, instead of yourself.

Don't buy this game if you haven't already. It's a hot mess on the PC, and that's besides all of the broken promises that Sean Murray and Hello Games left us with.  All of those broken promises will be rectified later down the line in paid DLC, I'm sure, based on Murray's quick turn around on the issue, so if you're a complete idiot, by all means, go ahead and pay $60 for a game that's worth maybe $15, then pay $45 for even more cut content that should've been in the original release.

Got it from a freebie loving friend as a gift, redeemed. Tried it on 2k, nope. Tried it on 4k, nope. Don't even try this on VR (Unless you wanna puke).  It's basically an apple and shell collecting simulator and a very, very unoptimized glitchy piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at that too. There's nothing MMO about it so the title is misleading, apparently the Dev bribing people for reviews on top of that. Everything about this is just, wrong.  If you somehow got it as a gift or by some mistake, and past the point of refund, leave it to idle master to rip the cards out of it's carcass and then shoot it in it's glitchy pixel head, and then cleanse it with fire just to make sure it's dead and stays that way.
Paid mods 2.0 - now with even more shady practices!

These developers obv dont play pc games      To begin with, the game is still buggy as hell, and the mechanics have many flaws. Walking around just feels weird. I cant even tell you how many times my car has been destroyed by zombies bashing on my doors.      When they are on my car bashing, i tend to quietly kill them by pressing "e", but guess what, "e" has plenty of binds to it, so instead i hop into my car and it takes too long to get back out, and then you repeat the process until you just melee it and your car is engulfed in flames.      Its a shame because I truly enjoy this game, but for being a game that is almost two years old with the same issues from launch is unacceptable. Now with the multiplayer,       while it is multiplayer, you must use the "xbox app" to play with friends, which was most likely done to expand the player-base, and makes sense because im sure not many ppl will play this on steam, and if you look at the achievements, they are rarely completed, which makes me think those ppl either returned the game or are stuck with it because they put 3 hours of playtime.      I wish they did something different with the multiplayer as well, what i was hoping was that you and your friends are the community and you guys can survive together in this zombie world, and can recruit members along your journey, but instead it's just your friend helping your community, which is fine, but sort of boring and adds nothing to the story.      I didnt even cover everything about whats wrong with the game, and there are things that they implemented well. however they can be outweighed easily by all the issues this game still has. Other issues i've experienced is frequent crashing/freezing, the audio being insanely loud at launch and the gun sounds are also extremely high pitch, the radio chatter is too quiet, and what I hate the most is the amount of noise your camp makes even thought everyone is quiet and no machines are running, as if you couldn't tell your community to keep it down a notch. Story-telling      If your looking for a game with good story-telling, or even a decent one, this is not the game. The narration is so awkward, especially when you first start a new game, its just three ppl in a circle speaking, but no one is moving their mouth, long pauses after someone says a line, and the voice acting is the worst i've ever heard, sounds like its from a school project.      If you don't mind the bugs and have the $30 plus tax, then i'd say go for it and give it a try, otherwise i'd say steer clear from this title, as it lacks certain content, such as being a multiplayer game, when it really is a single-player game with added multiplayer elements.

Hunter is a weak and frail â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ now and Jockey is overpowered. They introduced "new" and awful weapons that haven't even been animated properly and don't fit with the game's aesthetic. This game was not ready for release, this honestly feels like it's still in the early beta phase. - Being forced to make a microsoft account, I ask for DeadEndd, it's available. It gives me MochaCentaur instead.  - Campaign in co-op is incredibly unstable, 60 FPS is not possible and the game constantly shutters.  - EXP/Credit gains for Reach was completely removed from Campaign. Overall, MP only nets you them.  - Quite a number of achievements are bugged, one such example is killing 7 moa on the first mission.  - Co-op progression doesn't register properly, I spent the whole night yesterday doing the legendary campaign with a friend. The game claims I still have 3 missions to do on Legendary. This was without DC/leaving. I honestly could go on, I absolutely loved the Halo games back when I played them a lot on the 360. But this is by far the worst experience I've had with any Halo game, I'll update the review as they release patches and hopefully the game becomes more stable. But until then I simply can't recommend the game at all. Edit 1: After playing some MP games, the ping and stuff is decent. Compared to most launches anyway. My biggest issue with the game though, is the hitmarkers. With a DMR is originally takes 4-5 shots to the head to kill someone. I've noticed that people can survive up to 3 headshots afterwards with no shields. Not sure if this was always the case in the MCC but this was NOT the case in Reach. - Servers are decent enough, expecting the game to be fully stabilized  in MP this month - May it be Hitmarkers or server side, you can sometimes expect to have to pop a full clip of DMR ammo into someones skull to kill them. - The text box can be incredibly annoying, but everyone seems to use that instead of voice chatting. - Invasions are ranked only, which was not the case in Reach.  - Just like the campaign, you may expect FPS drops, but at least you can have a solid 60 in MP. Edit 3: This game is getting worse and worse now. Due to a large number of people being lazy they have decided to go afk during matchmaking games. The majority is the case for Grifball but can also be seen quite a bit in all game modes. The game remains to have no reporting, with the devs still sitting quiet this entire time since they released the game on pc. The MP database has went from 160k players the 1st week down to 24k.  All I can say is... They had 1 job and blew it. At least we can still look forward to the SP experience...

I'm a little surprised at the strong Steam reviews.  The more mediocre Metacritic reviews seem a little more accurate.  The graphics were very rudimentary.  I find it annoying to watch pixelated square head characters moving around reminiscent of early 1990's graphics.  The story was uninspiring.  It required almost no imagination and only repetitive clicking of the mouse button to get through.  The rhymes were bad but easily ignored.  The story was short.  It required only about 2 hours to play but I would not have even dedicated that to it but for the member who created the giveaway insisted that I play it and provide feedback.

Initially was a positive review... Changed this to reflect latest 20MB patch which now only allows 8 clicks per second when using auto clickers Devs somehow think people don't use auto clickers to play games like this? so my almost 700 hrs game time has been wasted, forced to use money because paywalls have been put in place. No where do devs stipulate you cannot use an auto clicker For an EA game this isn't the smartest thing to do, you've just gone and changed the rules when the game was hard enough as it was Game is ruined now... Totally avoid this game, you're going to spend months getting anywhere or you will be forced to spend real money EDIT so I decided after what I consider a completion of the game, to post my thoughts 1st things 1st, devs do respond to things that are broken, so if things have happened to you in game where money is involved or not, they will personally fix this, I like this and praise the devs for this care and attention: this is where the praise ends unfortunately So the game i have now clocked up 900+ hours and I found while it kept me occupied, there was very little to do that was rewarding. I was an active player so used an auto clicker (I advise to use one and it's not cheating as some suggest), the game stalls for some reason and I don't think the migration from Mobile platform to PC has worked well in favor of devs So you can complete this game without money and what I mean complete is 100% achiements, after that there is no real reason for me to continue It's a lot of time and I personally would not do this ever again, but the timing was right and I had spare time based on certain personal goals being achieved, given I pooled my efforts into this (being a fan of the TV show caught my attention so thought any meme could be a good meme). I soon recognised how much effort was required to get my 100% fulfilment, this was a social experiment gone horribly wrong, things changed in the game that made progression feel retarded, held back So I have already posted how auto clicker was nerfed, that wasn't so much an issue as the events were, which became a distraction of the main task, which is for me 100% achievements So these events, while had some nice extras, really all they do is hold you back from doing what youo're supposed to be doing, and it adds up to 125hrs? to the whole dynamic, and yes it's become weekly I don't like how the game has changed so rapidly like things have just been added to please the few paying customers? I don't know and I am not accusing, but asking a question, it just feels that a minority here is being catered for, ie the paying player that can and will get what they pay for, which is obviously an advantage, it doesn't mean non paying players are at a disadvantage, it means that that aspect of the game is being neglected The game is designed to create revenue, cash cows it needs to move to fiscal targets to be succesful Most players (this is an opinion) do not spend money so the driving force of this game, you guessed it is money Devs can do what they want, as long as there is a way of 100% achievements without money, I am all good for that, what doesn't gell well is when devs change the focus of the game mid way, or early on and these changes affect in my eyes the monetary value of the game I will explain, certain things early on which people spent money on changed to where newer players could potentially have to spend more money on or less, given the dynamics have changed Not good Also the fact of the matter that these things should have been worked out in EA, not full release which makes spending money in this game a bit of a gamble, to which my last point's measure This game with money becomes a bit of a gamble as you really do not know what you're getting when you buy the packs, there is not enough consistancy as you cannot sell anything you acquire, other than the cards you get (this is the bonus), but one player might spend more money achieving the same results as another, to me which is too random /TL:DR oh well, such is life... __________________________________________________________________________ I will leave everything here, BUT add that the devs actually do care about their community If I could leave a nuetral review, I would, but alas I cannot There has been some toxic behaviour in threads which devs have stated that using an auto clicker is NOT against ToS The devs are right in posting this and posted due to concerns of the players that use an auto clicker... Kudos to them for being transparent

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it,  Because this GAME gave me cancer anyway.

This game is only bearable with friends. Not to say this game is the most misleading early access title of all time, but there are many aspects of the game that are unacceptable in how they function especially how it was unable to keep pace with other titles or even learn from them in improving its own structural foundations. The most I can really say is, only play this if you have a solid group of friends to play with you. For as riddled with bugs and as clunky this is, asking for $35.00 when you can grab PUBG for $30.00 or Just Survive! for $20.00, I'm just mystified to how any of these funds aren't put to more effective use. I can't recommend this game to anyone due to the cluster-profanity it has become, being the poster child for the worst possible way an early access title could ever go (even No Man's Sky is beginning to redeem itself). If you really must get this, wait until it goes on sale I suppose.

I really wanted to be able to give this game a good review, but there's so much wrong with it. I like the game in that it's grindy and slow-ish paced but there's no fun. The first bug that I encountered was sometimes I would clip into rocks/structures. The next bug that I encountered was when Mun takes you to the other planets, more often than not she clips through the floor. Then sometimes travelling to the other planet the timer for Mun's visit would still count down and at the end of the timer she would disappear, ultimately leaving you stranded, causing a soft-lock. Sometimes monsters would spawn on Deiland, and they would literally walk off into the sky, unreachable. Ultimately causing yet another soft-lock. If i cook a lot of the same item and then start cooking another item it uses the same ingredients from the first recipe. In the final boss fight, one of the spiders spawned on the other side of the final door in the spaceship and the door cant be opened until you defeat the spider, so again, another soft lock. Locke was on my planet, and Mun visited. She invited Locke to work for her. After that I went to talk to Locke and dialogue for the Nymph came up asking if I could make him Nymph scent, and the nymph wasn't even on my planet. If you fish and meteors start falling, the planet continues to rotate after the meteors have fallen, meaning you can't see where to put the bob in order to catch a fish because the planet keeps rotating away from the pond. Making it really annoying and difficult. There's no flag set for all of the quests to be completed before the final boss fight so I ended up defeating the final boss about halfway though the game. I still have a couple quests left at this point because i'm nearly finished now. After Yuki quest line is finished you never see her again, which sucks. Granted you get to keep Bom, but he does nothing. The chickens... ALWAYS follow you around and CONSTANTLY get in your way. There's several places on all of the planets that look like you can walk on them but you actually can't because there's invisible walls placed literally everywhere. Everywhere is linear, except for your own planet. The quests are so jumbled up that a lot of the time the dialogue doesn't make any sense. I also found myself passing quests really quickly because I had already bought or crafted the items needed for the quests due to the fact I upgraded my farms, grew a tonne of melons and sold them all to the chef, I had 5 times as much money as I needed for everything in the game after grinding melons for 45mins. A lot of the items you can craft are literally only used once throughout the game. So much could have been done with this game and it's a real shame that it ended up the way it is. I will continue to play the game until I have unlocked all of the achievements, but after that I highly doubt i'll play it again. I got the game for free, and no I wouldn't buy it. I'd maybe buy it if it was half the asking price.
While it has a few moments of feeling like a 90's fps, it is riddled with bugs and a major lack of content that holds it back from being enjoyable.

I got this from a Steam friend - & how glad am I that I didn't pay for it... It's not horrible per se - just the most mediocre, 90's-ish, on-rails, WWII FPS; talk about damning with faint praise. Anyway, it's worth nowhere   sixteen quid - more like Â£3.99 at best. If you're a fan of '90s nostalgia from 2014' & enjoy overpaying for middle-of-the-road shooters, then   rush out & buy it -  this is   game! They said: "ENEMY FRONT is the first truly modern WW2 FPS, featuring stunning visuals, open-ended levels and a richly interactive combat experience that breaks out of the standard model of highly linear scripted FPS experiences, giving the player full freedom to own their playing style." My response: No. No, it isn't...
â™¥â™¥â™¥ me

3 days later still not playable, 13 hour queues to get in. The hype kids pull the usual "its early access noob", cause thats an acceptable excuse for anything. From the people that have got in: Its extremely geared towards clans with large amounts of people, solo players or groups of small people dont stand a chance if they are facing large clans. So unless you've got a lot of people ready to team up you're probably gonna end up getting ganked in the tutorial area by a large clan.

Honestly this whole old school retro graphics style looks a whole lot like lazily done artistically bankrupt low effort attempt at nostalgia, which only serves to turn me off from playing it. I'd say its just a step above the typical minecraft clone style fps and just woefully overrated. Theres probably better looking retro styled fps games out there to waste your time on >_>
Its not fun for me. Sadly i cannot get my refund.
VERY BAD GAME FULL CHEATER

Leaving Lyndow picturesquely walks through summery forests and vegetated fields, preluding to the technical quality of Eastshades' art direction, yet its deceptively brief and hollow journey can be surmised as a demonstration rather than a narrative-driven game. WHAT I LIKED: + One with nature. Lyndow is a bustling village with plenty of beautifully tranquil areas to explore. From majestic woods to a civilised tea house. It's an experience that revolves around world-building, introducing players to the Eastshade world and the style of game that is to come. It is undoubtedly a gorgeous game to look at, with hundreds of assets on the screen at one time and still performing optimally well. Leaves gently blowing in the wind. The crackles of flames in the fireplace. Each environment felt different when exploring and offered a few surprises along the way. + Master of the beads. One of those surprises was a bowl of beads that the player could interact with using the mouse. It's absolutely pointless, but ever so satisfying to watch beads roll around a spherical bowl. It's the small things in life... WHAT I DISLIKED: - An empty shell of beauty. Leaving Lyndow is unfortunately one-dimensional. It lacks characterisation of its protagonist, whom is leaving the titular village to explore vast regions, and other villagers including family members. It is thematically shallow, never really divulging in the hardship of waving goodbye to memories and upbringing. It's also lacking in purpose. For example, finding four straw dolls for the nephew granted no reward whatsoever. Regrettably, Leaving Lyndow resembled a painting without any interpretation. Even the "light puzzle" element of the forest wind chimes hand held the player after one or two replays of the melody. - A short advertisement. The studio has admitted that Leaving Lyndow was more of a trial to experience the process of shipping a game and garnering feedback for their big upcoming project Eastshade. And it's abundantly clear that this short walking simulator was nothing more than an advertisement for what was to come. It wets the palette, nothing more. Conceding to a paid technical demonstration, that would help supplement Eastshade's funds, rather than a fleshed out prequel/game. Oh, and by short, I mean 30 - 45 minutes... - Humans? Or dwarvish elves? The character models, despite every single one of them looking incredibly similar from a facial perspective, didn't suit the environments. At all. Their clunky limbs and murky colours contrasted with the vibrancy of Lyndow, consequently producing an unusual aesthetic that felt otherworldly (despite the fantasy setting...). VERDICT: 4/10 herbal teas

I don't feel like writing a long review, because you could talk about RuneScape forever, but I simply hate what it has become over the years. I used to be a regular player. Now I wouldn't touch it with a 10 foot pole. The game has a massive amount of content, but it should just be burnt with fire. Ever since they introduced microtransactions the game only went downhill. But I can't say they knew what they were doing with updates to various mechanics either. I won't be reviewing it properly. I invested enough time in it in the past and I now wish I could get it back. So now all I'm gonna say is RuneScape sucks.

The idea is great, the game looks cute so far but I cannot recommend it, in good consciousness of course. I really, really, really want to leave a thumb up, but I currently just can't.  If you have played Cities: Skylines or any other city-builder-game, you will know what I am talking about. Every single step of building or deleting roads/paths/railroads will be a huge frustration in this game. Yes, I have only played the Early Access so far, yes the game has a lot of potential and I do hope that especially those building tools will be upgraded and fixed, but currently they are really bad. Often you are not even able to build on hills - but the game does not even provide any flat maps. Also, another point I want to criticize is the fact that the buildings all already look post-soviet abandoned, shouldn't they look new and fancy if the game takes place in the Soviet Union?

I still don't recommend this game at its current price.  The game is very unstable and loves to CTD, especially when doing the 2k showcases.  Lots of the CAW parts have severe clipping issues, as well as some clipping issues while in-ring.  The graphics are nothing special; essentially being the same as 2k19, so nothing to rave about.  Overall game play and mechanics are not too bad, but could definitely be better.  Universe mode is improving, albeit slowly.  It still needs some work, but it's getting to a good place.  The 2k Showcases are actually not too bad, except for the constant CTD's.   When the Showcases have been stable, I've enjoyed the challenge (just fix the damn CTD's).  Overall I give this game a solid 5/10.  If they fix the CTD's, I would give it a 6 or 7.

This one was hard for me. I actually did like the Arctic Cruise part quite a bit (although I can't stand when the seals talk, seriously WHY). I did think it was way too short though. The actual design of the levels is quite lovely. There's a seal that says "egg". Overall, I don't really have a problem with Arctic Cruise besides it being short. But then there's Death Wish. There's some enjoyable challenges here, but then there's quite a few that are just awful because of the way that they try to challenge you -- it's just not a good way of doing it and in order to 100% the game, you HAVE to finish the death wishes. IMO this would've been a far better idea for a new game+ or master mode or whatever that overall increases the difficulty of the base game to be harder instead of doing this challenge mode where you have to finish levels in a certain amount of jumps or ones where you can't even jump at all... or boss rush where if you move onto a boss with 1 out of 4 health left, if you die then you respawn with ONE OUT OF FOUR HEALTH AND YOU ONLY HAVE THREE LIVES TOTAL. Ugh. I will admit that I do really love the time rift collapses of Death Wish. The music's awesome and the levels look really neat with a sense of "everything's falling apart". Unfortunately though I think I'm going to have to not recommend this DLC. A Hat in Time set the bar very high in terms for what DLC for the game should meet or exceed, but with Arctic Cruise being too short and Death Wish being painful in one of the worst ways it can be, this DLC does not meet that bar.

So... What can I say about this game, I mean its okay I guess.. I like graphics and futuristic stuff, but it's not original and it's nothing new in video games, so I will gonna say that this game is okay, but for single player and of course Zombies, but oh my lord, that multiplayer mode, :D, it's a complete joke, bad rip off from Black Ops 3, but thats kinda okay, the worst thing is cheaters, cheaters, almost, like, second to third match and booom there you have it.. One in game, minimum... I mean, don't get me wrong, Infinity Ward tried something, they created this game from engine built same for CoD Ghosts (I mean just look at the animations, lower textures, some sounds and icons in game), and the worst part is... THIS GAME SUFFERS FROM SAME SIMPTOMS AS GHOSTS on PC :D, input lag, mouse lag, FPS randomly drop, and oh my god, you will need a beast, because r9 290x can't hit 1080p - 60 fps on very low textures - complete joke of optimization... So, I can only recommend you to get Black Ops 3 it's a superb game, but this, it's a rip off of BO3, Ghosts, MW3, even it got a variety map pack from older CoDs... And yeap, I only recommend it for Single Player and Zombies, it's awesome only there - MP only with hardened bots... Also, purchase PS4 copy, its much better optimized then PCs.

MUH BANNERLORD! It's missing something new and innovating. Lots of weird design decisions. Towns are rather dull and lacks atmosphere and polish, it's very quiet like it's missing tons of amient sounds. Music is nice but gets on your nerve when its played on repeat. Why not has something more ambient and subtle, to build immersion. Overall sound and music needs a lot of work still. where is all the quests and random encounters? They need to add some more events and dynamic behaviour to make it more interesting to replay. I can't imagining playing this over and over when it's so much the same. The world feels very empty, looters, caravans and lords is all you pretty much see. A lot of reused scenes and towns. Combat is decent but very much the same as Warband, AI seems to be rather broken at times. Companions get stuck, and armies moshpit with no tactics or realistic battle behaviour. I'm also not seeing much in the Crusader Kings 4x type content. Overall you should probably wait and see if they are willing to create something interesting here. EDIT:  It also randomly crash, making it unplayable at certain criterias. Lol the crash reporter is also bugged. Why does my arab character sound like a british hooligan? Breaks immersion. Some quests are really broken. They make the game crash no matter what. Quest giver: ERROR_COMMENT_STRING variable has not been set before. Game keeps crashing, so it's unplayable for some people. Not worth the money.

Don't let yourself fooled by its cartoonish look! This is another awful amateur game lazily made with Unity. The game starts with a silly but somehow funny 1 minute intro featuring our hero, a blue-greenish crab-looking alien with four eyes, a high pitched voice and a laser pistol telling how he got into deep trouble. So far, so good. But once we're past the intro, things go downhill very quickly... First of all, the Main menu is not even adapted properly as the Start and Exit buttons are cut offscreen. Hmmm, maybe the game was made with 4:3 ratio in mind? Okay, then. I change the ratio but see not improvement. In fact, the issue is even more noticeable so I switch back to 16:9 ratio. This is bad omen... What comes next is a horrendous third person shooter plagued with poor shooting mechanics, clunky controls, poor level design, forgettable encounters as well as performance issues. Laser pistol, shotgun and machine gun act pretty much like hitscan weapons with cheap SFX. Movements are very stiff and the fact that our character can get stuck so easily makes the experience even worse. Levels are narrow and flat terrains that simply consist of walking straight toward the exit. Enemies cannot be shot at until they have been "agro" and don't flinch when taking damage. Not to mention that their walking or running animations look more like sliding than anything. As for the technical aspect, the framerate will sometimes drop below 30fps. I made it through the three first levels but couldn't complete the last one since I didn't know what to do. Gamer beware... You're in for a fraud... Rating: 2.5 / 10

Hitman 2 is a very lackluster title. The core mission set for this game is 6 missions + time based exclusive missions released every month.  It is expected that after you finish the very short campaign that you keep replaying the same missions over and over to explore other ways to complete these missions. The cover for the lackluster story and missions is that the levels are ment to be a sandbox for the player to decide how they wish to proceed with a mission. Although I have enjoyed replaying the missions, the campaign and its story are extremely lacking for a $84 AUD game (base price without dlcs or special editions). It is like having a bowl of ice cream without any toppings and its just one scoop. Its good but it really is missing a large amount of content that can be only supplemented though spending more money on dlcs and upgrades.  The game hints you into buying additional campaign missions from the previous episodic hitman release a few years ago and the special edition pre-order mission offered for that game as patient zero. It has a lot to be desired.  If you're interested in playing this game, get it while its on special but be warned that you'll go right though the campaign quick so you'll probs want all the content in a special edition in about a year. We'll see if it improves but atm its only worth the buy if you've got money to waste.  Suggest buying Hitman Absolution instead if you want a full proper game.

Lots of fun units... but the pirate economy  ssuuUUUUUuuUUCCCccKKKSSSS they basically mixed chaos, skaven, and the vamps together in terms of campaign mechanics, to an unfortunate result! With the regular vampire counts u get a much stronger economy, which means many more armies, and even though zombies and skeletons are technically chaff, they don't feel nearly as fragile as low tier pirates with the pirates ur lucky to maintain 3 armies max before the upkeep drags you down buildings are outrageously expensive for what they give(including pirate coves) yes u have lots of gunpowder units, but most of them suck! thunderers are better than even the deck gunners! their siege unit crews crumble as soon as they take damage, so good luck keeping your valuable back line alive This faction requires brain dead a.i. to survive, but in a head to head campaign they get steamrolled. absolutely NOT WORTH THE PRICE!!!!!!   a total rip off

The base gameplay is alright. The shooting is fun enough, and the very well-made animations never seem to become tiresome to watch. Everything else wasn't done right. My biggest gripe is exploration: while the game starts strong in this regard, soon enough the level design becomes nothing more than a series of gauntlet rooms that are connected by one-way drops and doors, even though there is absolutely no reason why they need to be one-way. If you decide you want to go back and look for some secrets, you have to restart the entire level (and sit through all the unskippable cutscenes again!). It doesn't help that there are no manual saves, only checkpoints; and there are plenty of bottomless pits to fall into, so if you are the sort of person who prefers to explore every nook and cranny over using a guide, get ready to restart from some annoying checkpoints lots of times. Also, one of the collectibles uses a reference to the original game, so if you never played that, you are very unlikely to find it. The challenges feel more like fetch quests than challenges. Annoying chores that discourage you to approach fights the way you'd want to. And on top of all that, most of the time you have to look at the game through a horrible looking piss filter. The original doom games used plenty of colours, including vibrant blues; in this one, you don't get anything other than gray and orange. Don't pay full price for this.

*Review updated 10/10/2020: Issue still unresolved.  500MB update is taking longer than an hour to pre-allocate.  This is the 5th consecutive update without any resolution or even acknowledgement by the developers.  As it stands, Mordhau's recent updates have been taking uncharacteristically long to download and install.  We are talking in the range of hours for updates that sometimes are as small as 2MB.  This has happened a total of 4* times for me, personally, in the last few weeks.  Forum posts and steam community posts indicate that it's happening to a lot of other users as well.  Yes, I confirmed that this was not an issue with my hardware or the drive on which it was installed.   There has been no public recognition of this issue by the developers, to my knowledge.  I bought this game, I own it, and you, the developers, are preventing me from playing it when I want to.  I therefore consider my money to have been taken from me.  I paid for this product with the expectation that it would be mine, to use at my discretion, and that the developers would follow best practices in their updates and content patching.  I did not pay to RENT this game, regardless of how cleverly their lawyers have worded their EULA to make that the case, legally; I BOUGHT it.  Software is different from a physical object, but as a direct result of the way that the developers programmed their updates, it is no longer "my game" for several hours at a time, and this wouldn't be a big deal, except for the glaring fact that: THIS HAS NEVER HAPPENED BEFORE WITH ANY OTHER GAME IN OVER 15 YEARS ON STEAM.  That's why I'm upset.  Games have to update, I get it, but come on..  5 hours to preallocate disc space for a 2MB update?  â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off, seriously.  I've never felt so flipped off by a purchase in my entire life.  Imagine buying a car, and then watching as the manufacturers take it out on a road trip for a week instead of doing maintenance on it for an hour like you'd expected.  You'd be â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ livid.  You'd have grounds to sue.  This is the same damn thing, just in another medium. This review will now permanently remain negative for the aforementioned reasons, despite the fact that Mordhau is actually quite fun to play... So long as you can launch and play it on the same day that you started an update.

I get that's sort of a point of the game, but it happens WAY too often with things added in aside from just a card draw (ex. multicast and other proc chances).  Wait for Valve to fix the game some more before getting (hopefully they'll add in an actual way to progress while playing too).
