What a horroble experience. Some Games better be unplayed for ever. At first it does not seem too bad, you start in a somewhat good looking place with chill music. You then activate the first tablet and don't know what to do, so you try climbing everything untill you fall down, which is the solution. You then get teleported in a disgusting looking place where all essential graphics where missing. At first I thaught the graphics glitched out during the loading but no. The game does look like this. You then enter the three Puzzles. 1st Puzzle: No graphics as well. When I checked the store page, I just confirmed myself that these places are supposed to look like that. You then complete the Puzzle even though the jumping is insanely janky and horrible. 2nd Puzzle: The Labyrinth. Holy crap was that annoying. It took my ages to find the last stone. No wonders since it does not glow (they normally do) and lies in complete darkness. I just found this on accident because the screen said I could pick something up here. 3rd Puzzle: The absolute worst of all. The shrine in absolute darkness. No lightning at all. I had to remeove all the gamme-setting-files in the game files and had to turn down the graphics on low in the options so I can slightly, very slightly, see the ground If I look directly down. You then need to find the solution to the Puzzle which is absolutely unclear at all. I tried everything for like 15 minutes untill I checked the discussion tab on steam. The solution seriously is to have all doors open except the first one on the left (The door you probably opend first). I do not recommend this game to anyone ever.

My heart hurts. I had such high hopes for Akash: Path of the Five. The moment I discovered that the fully-voiced otome VN was only available on the PS4, Iâ€™d become instantly envious.  And when news hit that it was being ported to PC, I was downright ecstatic. But after having finally played through everything the game has to offer, I canâ€™t help but feel let down. Donâ€™t get me wrong, even if my expectations were more tempered going in, Iâ€™d still be glum right now. Akash is beautiful, but empty, ambitious, yet mediocre...and despite the couple things it does right, it does a lot wrong. A LOT. The premise itself may be a problem for some readers. Our story focuses on Aurora, the first female elemental born in over 200 years. As a female, she is highly-desired by the men in her village, mostly because the â€œfruitâ€ of their union is guaranteed to be pureblood, and much more powerful than the half-breeds that result from elemental/human pairings. She spends the early portion of the game struggling with blatant sexism by most of the other elementals (except for her prospective beaus, because of course). And even though the story itself is critical of this view, itâ€™s something that will surely prove uncomfortable for some. I personally had a hard time watching Aurora getting talked down to and harassed by some of the other characters. Still, I had hopes that she would eventually challenge the views of her people, but it never happens. Everything is resolved through a convenient bit of  , after which everyone lives happily ever after, except for me as the reader, apparently.  Then thereâ€™s the â€œpeace treatyâ€ between the humans and elementals that pretty much gives the elementals free reign over the human women for baby-making purposes. Sure, the women have to agree to it, but one night of fun in exchange for 9 months of pregnancy, only to have your child whisked away afterwards never to be seen again...that doesnâ€™t seem like such a great deal to me. But donâ€™t worry, the humans will be written as disgusting, rude, dim-witted beings, so you wonâ€™t have to feel bad about the elementals taking advantage of them. Iâ€™m not even sure what the humans get out of the agreement, though, other than the assurance that the elementals wonâ€™t murder them. And thatâ€™s only one of a dozen details that are never fully explained.  So much of the story is vaguely-detailed that I often found myself confused over certain plot points, and I blame a lot of that on important elements being glossed over so quickly that they arenâ€™t given enough time to take hold. Outside of the prologue text, almost everything we know about the elementals is mentioned in passing, then barely referenced again. I wanted to learn more about this world and its inhabitants, to have the fuzzy details in my mind explained and elaborated upon. I wanted to know why female elementals grew so rare. What exactly was the Goddess pendant, and where did it really come from?   I had hoped the answers would have been in the charactersâ€™ story routes, but alas...they are not. Every single route, save for Danielâ€™s brief diversion, plays out EXACTLY the same way; even the exposition is almost entirely copy/paste (and much of it unskippable, too). Each guyâ€™s story ends in the exact same place and in the exact same way. And the few times you actually do make a decision that changes the outcome, instead of actually seeing it play out, you get a few pages of epilogue text, then itâ€™s game over. I havenâ€™t read a visual novel this repetitive since  , and that is NOT a ringing endorsement. But at least the romances are good, right? RIGHT?!? Well, Iâ€™ve forgiven worse stories as long as the romances were enjoyable, but all of the guys here are so one-dimensional itâ€™s almost painful. I donâ€™t mind stereotypical romances as long as the characters are well-developed and entertaining to pursue, but everyone here is essentially their trope, their entire backstories a few throwaway lines in between confessions of love and kisses, and thatâ€™s it. Lux is the childhood friend, Rocco the flirt, Ignatius the tsundere, Caspian the kuudere, and Rowan the dumb, but lovable, jock. Thatâ€™s all you need to know. Everything else about their personalities is left up to the voice actors. I do need to make mention that had the voice acting not been a selling point for the game, I'd probably have turned it off. Voice acting isnâ€™t a big deal to me. I can live without it, and quite often mute it, especially if I find it grating. I donâ€™t mind English voice acting, either, so this isnâ€™t a Japanese vs. English thing with me. But while I can say with certainty the voice work here is quality, and I know that most of these actors are veterans when it comes to the craft, the delivery is almost cartoonish at times. I keep thinking these characters would fit perfectly in an RPG with how their voices often sound like caricatures of themselves. Of the lot, only Lux stirred anything within me, and even his â€œsweet boyâ€ act started to get old towards the end.  And donâ€™t even get me started on Rocco. Iâ€™m sure Andrew Love is a fine voice actor, but the amount of sleaze in his â€œflirtyâ€ performance made me squirm more from discomfort than attraction.  So, is there anything that I actually like about Akash? Well, the character sprites are really detailed and attractively drawn, and a good half of the CGs are gorgeous, despite the other half being merely serviceable. The soundtrack features several lovely pieces, and I especially enjoy the composerâ€™s piano work. I might even grab the DLC at some point just for the â€œactionâ€ theme, which has a string of piano chords that reminds me of   of all time. Other than that, though? I honestly wasnâ€™t intent on criticizing this game as much as I have, but as the words flowed from my fingertips, and my feelings of disappointment and regret began to take form, I couldnâ€™t stop myself. Akash: Path of the Five could have been SO much more than it is. Unfortunately, I blame most of its deficiencies on the writing. In a genre where storytelling is 75% of what makes a game, you cannot fail at the writing. It doesnâ€™t matter how hot the guys are or how â€œgoodâ€ the voice acting is, a story is only as good as the words that compose it, and not a letter more.

This game is garbage. I can say that with confidence because i put 300 hours into this game and say that it is garbage. It was pretty fun grinding the game, but omg the game is really broken. Ther servers are trash and I can't think of a game that i played where some type of glitch didn't happen. The game never has any updates and when it does, it's minor fixes. THAT I DONT EVEN REALIZE. I think when they come out with a game they start working on the next game right away. I find it hard to believe that any devs are working on this game right now. The game is also littered with a bunch of cheaters. Some keep it hidden so they don't get caught, but the other 99% make it so obvious. Like arms so big it reaches the floor, hitting every shot possible, and just giant monsters. The game is also dominated by try hards. and another thing to add is the game is EXETREMELY REPETITIVE. The only fun part is the park, but as i said it is filled with cheaters and try hards. It also gives you barely any vc, which is the in game currency used to upgrade your player. Vc is everything and the only way to get it is to spam playing the nba which is fun for about 1 season and then it is just the same thing over and over again. To add one final comment on this review. This game is garbage.

One of the biggest disappointments for a triple-A title, let alone a Star Wars title, in recent years.  This (obvious) PC port of the 360/PS3 Star Wars game is hopelessly flawed by lucratively overpowered enemies, broken maps, ZERO in-game graphics options, terrible camera angles, and glitchy controls. There is no checkpoint/quicksave system, requiring you to redo the insane boss battles over and over again.  The battles? Boss battles should be moderately enjoyable, to be able to pull off some combo attacks. Well, no. Every boss has unavoidable attacks and will annihilate you before you have any chance to get the boss to 50% health. Stick to Battlefront II or any of the other fantastic Star Wars titles, skip this miserable mess.

I got the game expecting another metro game but honestly I cannot recommend this game. Overall it's clunky, they removed the health regen entirely and enemies have weird phases where at one point they aim like snipers and another they aim like stormtroopers so here is all I can say. Pros: - Beautiful game - Interesting enviornments - Enjoyable story Cons: - No health regen makes the game feel grindy because you need to constantly craft syringes - Obnoxious "blood splatter" effect on the corners of your screen even if you're lightly hurt - The smallest drops causes you to take damage - Enemy AI is just upsetting when it comes to humans Conclusion: I would only recommend buying this game when it goes on sale and even then expect a lot of nuisances and clunkiness that you wouldn't otherwise see in the other metro games. I feel all development went into the graphics rather than actualy gameplay.

Game is bugged on Windows 10 currently. There's an automatic "brainclap" ability that triggers upon killing certain thresholds of enemies. It will cause your game to totally freeze up, and there's no resolving it.  Game is busted/unplayable on Windows 10 as a result.
